subject: Gardening
title: Roots That Hear Water
description: A quick, practical guide to Roots That Hear Water.

hook.text: Pea roots grow toward the sound of flowing waterâ€”even when no moisture is present. They listen.

buildup.text: Researchers at the University of Western Australia tested roots in dry soil near buried water pipes.

discovery.text: Roots consistently grew toward the pipe with flowing water, ignoring silent pipes at the same distance.

twist.text: When moisture and sound conflicted, roots followed sound. Vibration was a more reliable signal than humidity.

climax.text: Plants may use acoustic signals underground in ways science is only beginning to understand.

punchline.text: Roots navigate underground by listening, not guessing.

quiz.question: What did University of Western Australia researchers discover about pea roots?
options: Roots grew toward the sound of flowing water even without moisture
Roots grew faster when exposed to classical music vibrations
Roots avoided any source of underground vibration
